w:r.w:t: In this project, we use the rigid body motion model to simulate the roll of a dice.
The dice is represented by 8 mass points at corners of the cube.
The ground is modelled as a “very stiff trampoline”. In the 3D space
Mass points receive an upward normal force proportional to how deep it penetrates the ground:
is the vertical component of the
The collision with the ground should transfer some mechanical energy to heat. A damping force is added whenever the mass point is below
is the vertical component of the velocity of the mass point.
We do not model static friction since we call the end of the simulation
If we compute the moment of inertia
, we will overestimate, since a real dice has uniform concentration of mass throughout the cube.
Fortunately, we can simply replace the value of
Since the matrix is invariant to rotation, we do not need to update
The radius of the dice is
The initial height of the dice is
If you drop a basketball with a backward spin, it is likely to bounce up with a forward spin
. That is because the ball stores energy as rotational elastic deformation as it hits the ground.
Since we model the dice as a rigid body, we will lose this effect.
is the dominant factor in the interaction
We do not model for ground deformation or air drag.
Because the corners of the dice are infinitely sharp right angles, the dice will not
trigger the precession effect. Real dices can spin rapidly on their corner for a long time because the precession effect helps them self-stabilize.
is a major deviation of our model from reality.
The potential energy of the dice when it is standing on its edge is
. This is the critical threshold for the dice to flip over and change face.

To decide which face is facing upwards, the program takes the highest four points and lookup which face it is.

Let us take a simpler example. Consider a ball climbing a hill.

When the initial kinetic energy of the ball equals to the potential energy the ball would have at the top,
the hill? If so, then the ball must pass the top of the hill with some non-zero velocity. This breaks the conservation of energy, hence impossible. Will the ball return to where it start
, either at the top or before the top.
Can the ball reach zero velocity at the top? If we rewind time from the situation where the ball sits still at the
we see that the ball will never
reach its initial condition in finite time, hence impossible.
Can the ball reach zero velocity before reaching the top? Again, the conservation of energy would be broken.
In conclusion, the ball will neither roll
the hill nor return to where it starts.
The ball will approach the top of the hill as

There seems to be a periodic pattern in this section of
A valid question is: are these different cells, or many 2D slices of the same 6D cell?

Theoretically, programming could answer this question. However, that requires traversing the 6D space to see if the slices are connected. The high dimensionality raises the time complexity of the program very fast. This is a common obstacle for many of our inquiries in this project: high dimensional data are hard to compute, and even harder to visualize.
The cause of this repetition of structure is unknown.
Higher damping coefficient leads to less chaotic

To analyze the “topology” of the throws, we make the program remember the sequence of points contacting the ground.
’s to be topologically the same if the ground contact history is identical.
The three rolls in the image turns out to be topologically different.
can thus be further divided into smaller cells according to ground contact history.)

to 2 and 3, we used base vectors that are not perpendicular to one another:
Future analysis should keep base vectors perpendicular, otherwise the resulting scatter plot may be skewed.
